text: Pigeon-shooting contests were a popular sport in the 1800s - some competitions killed 60k birds - until the passenger pigeon went extinct and animal rights activists got the sport banned. Shooters scrambled to invent a substitute - the clay pigeon - which sport shooters still use as targets.🪶🗃️📗

I #amwriting on digital colourization of still #photographs - and news like this makes me want to bang my head on my desk. I don't know exactly why: the use of photographic images to create 'human' encounters? And a sense that software is being developed just for the sake of developing software. 🗃️📷

#OTD in 1942, the Swinomish Indian Reservation plans to lay off its Japanese workers. Eight Japanese nationals worked as oyster openers but four were fired after the attack on Pearl Harbor. Complaints from local residents and the presence of nearby forts were the primary concerns.
🗃 #skystorians

Gould gets an unjustifiably bad rap from professional historians and philosophers. It’s as if we resent him for his exceptional talent as a prose stylist, so dismiss him as a dilettante or “mere popularizer.” 

He is sometimes wrong but *always* interesting. I’d take that.

#HistSTM #PhilSci 🧪🐋🌱🗃️🧠

A day late, but eel posts are for weekday, so...

There aren't snakes in Ireland, but there are eels! And with no serpents, eels made for good metaphorical stand-ins. Super-useful. Need a snake or a serpent? Use an eel!

Good thing Patrick left the eels alone, isn't it?
🧪🗃️

153 years ago today, Parisian women stepped between French troops & cannon, calling soldiers to recognize their alliance with the people, not the reactionary government. Turning on their leaders, the militaries joined working class Parisians, French leaders fled the city, & the Paris Commune began!🗃️

“Once, with hand-grenades in my shopping bag, I travelled in a train so full I had to stand against a German NCO.” 

#OnThisDay, 18 Mar 1943, Francine Agazarian arrives in Nazi-occupied France as part of the Special Operations Executive.

The First Minnesota Regiment engaged Confederates at Gettysburg on July 2, 1863 with 262 men. Of that number only 47 returned unscathed. I say keep it. #CivilWarMemory 🗃️ www.twincities.com/2017/08/20/m...

What I find interesting is that the ease with which we reference the Civil War, in exploring our current state of affairs, suggests that other moments in American history, that may be more instructive, have been forgotten. The Civil War may not be as helpful here as some might think. 🗃️

It’s the skinniest bit of the Americas, which has always defined its potential to outsiders. Come take a look at the photos and cartoons that tell the complex, fascinating history of Panama and its Canal. 🗃️

This is a reminder (to me at least—maybe others don’t need it) that every artifact from the past is a trace.

It’s not the thing that then existed; it’s a remnant. Even after it’s restored, we can’t ever experience it as it was experienced then. We just see a more or less imperfect avatar of it.

🧠🗃️

#OTD in 1942, George Takao, a Japanese American in Seattle, was stabbed by a Filipino attacker after an argument about the war. The dispute began after midnight on a bus as Takao was going to work. The incident is an example of the high wartime tension in the Asian American community.
🗃 #skystorians

🗃️ Here's the thing about that AHA summary of history ed in TIME & why it's so damaging in this moment.

Classrooms have always been the most negotiable spaces in schooling. 

Of course teachers go off (text)book. Of course teachers put their lessons together. This is not new in history ed. 1/

Packed room this morning to talk about women - mostly not entirely white middling women - as key and canny users and creators of capital in antebellum US. 🗃️ Thanks to Hannah, Amanda, and Ann for their great papers.

“Ultimately, what history teachers teach their students about …bears little resemblance to what partisan culture warriors argue about.”

There is no both-sidesism in this piece. It does not reflect an anti-intellectual bias. It points to what I've seen in my 20 years working with history educators. The best teachers see history as a way of thinking. They are not pushing politics or ideology on students. 🗃️

America had big dreams for imported ostriches in the 1890s - boosters expected them to become just as synonymous with California as raisins and oranges. These dreams went bust by 1915, but ostriches found a home in proto-amusement parks.🪶🗃️

birdhistory.substack.com/p/the-ostric...

It's Pi Day, so let's talk about eel pie!

Eel pie has been an important English food for a long time. Medieval cookbooks often included eel pie recipes, & everyone from peasants to kings at them.

In 1256, Henry III demanded eel pies from his bailiff at Fetcham! 1/7
🧪🗃️

I got my grandparents' tattered OS map back from the framers.

They used it when they moved from Belfast to Devizes, Dorset & spent their weekends exploring.

Despite its shabbiness, they brought it to Tasmania when they emigrated. Then, it hid among my parents' books.

Now, it hangs on my wall. 🗃️

In the 1920s apparently Washington used inmates to raise the state's game birds. The American Game Protective Association called it "wholesome work" that would "keep them from falling back into evil ways and prevent them from being subjected to temptations of larger cities."🪶🗃️

So Lent's here & you're gettin' hungry. What do you do?

Well, if you're the unpleasant 13th C. knight Gilbert de Clare, you're in luck. Because on Shrove Tuesday fishermen from Tonbridge will pay you 20 large eels & 1500 small eels (60 sticks) in rents.

Problem solved!

Many history instructors use the five Cs of historical thinking, but should there be a sixth? The producers of Dig: A History Podcast make a case for adding “continuity” to this popular framework. 🗃️

Since 2007, many have used the 5 Cs of historical thinking in their teaching. Yet the four producers of Dig: A History Podcast argue in #AHAPerspectives that an essential 6th C is missing from that framework. 🗃️

#OTD in 1942, a Seattle teacher writes a letter criticizing Japanese American students. She fears being labeled as "unfair" but quesitons the loyalty of the students. She adds, "we have just had a patriotic assembly with two Japanese talking on Lincoln and Wilson. My blood boiled."
